com.davidsoergel.trees

Interface HierarchyNode<T,I extends HierarchyNode<T,I>>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Iterable<I>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    DoubleHierarchicalTypedProperties<I,J,K,V,C,H>, ExtendedDoubleHierarchicalTypedProperties<S,H>, ExtendedHierarchicalTypedPropertyNode<K,V,H>, HierarchicalStringObjectMap<C>, HierarchicalTypedPropertyNode<K,V,H>, LengthWeightHierarchyNode<T,I>, PhylogenyNode<T>, ResultCollector, RootedPhylogeny<T>, SerializableDoubleHierarchicalTypedProperties<S>, SerializablePhylogenyNode<T>, SerializableRootedPhylogeny<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractDoubleHierarchicalTypedProperties, AbstractExtendedHierarchicalTypedPropertyNode, AbstractHierarchicalTypedPropertyNode, AbstractHierarchyNode, AbstractRootedPhylogeny, AbstractSerializableDoubleHierarchicalTypedProperties, BasicHierarchicalStringObjectMap, BasicHierarchicalTypedPropertyNode, BasicPhylogenyNode, BasicRootedPhylogeny, ExtendedHierarchicalTypedPropertyNodeImpl, ImmutableHierarchyNode, ImmutableSortedSetHierarchyNode, ListHierarchyNode, SerializableHierarchicalTypedPropertyNode, SetHierarchyNode

    public interface HierarchyNode<T,I extends HierarchyNode<T,I>>
extends Iterable<I>
    A node in a simple hierarchy, where a value of the given generic type is attached at each node. A node may have any number of children, which are also HierarchyNodes of the same generic type. The type of Collection that holds the children is up to the implementation, so they may or may not be ordered.
    Version:
    $Id: HierarchyNode.java 524 2009-10-10 07:55:47Z soergel $
    Author:
    David Soergel

      • newChild

        I newChild(T payload)
        Creates a new child node of the appropriate type. Note that the payload must be provided up front; this helps the child be more immutable than it otherwise would be (e.g. newChild() followed by setPayload()).
        Returns:
        the new child node

      • setParent

        void setParent(I parent)
        Sets the parent node; also informs the parent node via addChild() so that it can maintain the reverse link, if needed.
        Parameters:
        parent -

      • registerChild

        void registerChild(I a)
        Adds a child node. Does not update the child's parent link! The relationship is primarily owned by the child, so child.setParent() should call this method, not the other way around.
        Parameters:
        a - the child node to add

      • unregisterChild

        void unregisterChild(I a)
        Removes a child node. Does not update the child's parent link! The relationship is primarily owned by the child, so child.setParent() should call this method, not the other way around.
        Parameters:
        a - the child node to add

      • depthFirstIterator

        DepthFirstTreeIterator<T,I> depthFirstIterator()
        Get an iterator that returns all the nodes of the tree in depth-first order. The breadth ordering may or may not be defined, depending on the HierarchyNode implementation. We provide this depth-first iterator explicitly even though the HierarchyNode is itself iterable, because the default iterator may be breadth-first or something else.
        Returns:
        the DepthFirstTreeIterator

      • getSelfNode

        HierarchyNode<T,I> getSelfNode()
        In some cases we need to wrap a HierarchyNode in another object that provides a facade. In this case, wthis method return the underlying object; otherwise it just returns this.
        Returns:
        the most raw available HierarchyNode embedded within this facade (perhps just this object itself)

        int countDescendantsIncludingThis()
